Tuning the crystalline and electronic structure of ZrO2 via oxygen vacancies and nano-structuring for polysulfides conversion in lithium-sulfur batteries Shengnan Fu a Chaowei Hu a Jing Li a Hongtao Cui a Yuanyuan Liu a Kaihua Liu a Yanzhao Yang b Meiri Wang a ⁎ a Shandong Key Laboratory for Chemical Engineering and Processing, School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264000, Shandong, China Shandong Key Laboratory for Chemical Engineering and Processing School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Yantai University Yantai Shandong 264000 China Shandong Key Laboratory for Chemical Engineering and Processing, School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264000, Shandong, China b Key Laboratory for Special Functional Aggregate Materials of Education Ministry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, Shandong, China Key Laboratory for Special Functional Aggregate Materials of Education Ministry School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shandong University Jinan Shandong 250100 China Key Laboratory for Special Functional Aggregate Materials of Education Ministry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The tetragonal phases ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH with sufficient oxygen vacancies as an efficient sulfur mediator modified separator are successfully obtained at the nanoscale with the help of –OH functional groups to trap and catalytic polysulfides conversion. The recent emergence of tetragonal phases zirconium dioxide (ZrO2) with vacancies has generated significant interest as a highly efficient and stable electrocatalyst with potential applications in trapping polysulfides and facilitating rapid conversion in lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). However, the reduction of ZrO2 is challenging, even under strong reducing atmospheres at high temperatures and pressures. Consequently, the limited presence of oxygen vacancies results in insufficient active sites and reaction interfaces, thereby hindering practical implementation. Herein, we successfully introduced abundant oxygen vacancies into ZrO2 at the nanoscale with the help of carbon nanotubes (CNTs-OH) through hydrogen-etching at lower temperatures and pressures. The introduced oxygen vacancies on ZrO2− x /CNTs-OH can effectively rearrange charge distribution, enhance sulfiphilicity and increase active sites, contributing to high ionic and electronic transfer kinetics, strong binding energy and low redox barriers between polysulfides and ZrO2− x . These findings have been experimentally validated and supported by theory calculations. As a result, LSBs assembled with the ZrO2− x /CNTs-OH modified separators demonstrate excellent rate performance, superior cycling stability, and ultra-high sulfur utilization. Especially, at high sulfur loading of 6 mg cm−2, the area capacity is still up to 6.3 mA h cm−2. This work provides valuable insights into the structural and functional optimization of electrocatalysts for batteries. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Oxygen vacancies Zirconium dioxide/carbon nanotubes with –OH Improved redox kinetics Superior cycling stability 1 Introduction With the rapid growth of the low-carbon economy, there is an increasing demand for secondary batteries in portable electronic devices and electric vehicles that offer high energy density and long cycling life [1,2]. Lithium sulfur batteries (LSBs), which consist of elemental sulfur and lithium metal, hold great promise due to their exceptional theoretical energy density, cost-effectiveness, and environmental friendliness. Despite all the above advantages, LSBs still have not realized the commercialization because of several challenging issues. For example, the non-conductive nature of elemental sulfur, as well as the resulting Li2S and Li2S2 end products, hinders the reaction kinetics of polysulfides and results in poor rate performance [3–5]. Moreover, the polysulfides generated during the sulfur oxidation and reduction process dissolve in the electrolyte. As Li+ migrate, the polysulfides diffuse to the anode and react with lithium, leading to low utilization of active materials and rapid capacity decay [6–9]. To address the aforementioned challenges, numerous strategies have been proposed to enhance sulfur host catalysis and improve the capture ability for polysulfides. Among these strategies, the modification of the separator using sulfur mediators has emerged as an efficient approach [10]. An exemplary instance is the utilization of carbon paper, as demonstrated by Manthiram et al. [11], which optimizes the cathode of the battery and enhances sulfur utilization. Subsequently, various carbon materials (porous carbon [12,13], carbon nanotubes [14], graphene [15–17], etc.) have been employed for separator modification. However, due to their non-polar nature and limited interaction forces with lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), carbon materials exhibit constrained LiPSs adsorption capability [18–20]. As a result, it has been suggested that polar materials, including metal oxides, metal phosphides, and metal sulfides, could offer strong interactions with LiPSs for effective anchoring or possess excellent catalytic properties to enhance polysulfide conversion kinetics. Nonetheless, their practical application is hindered by relatively poor physicochemical stability and a scarcity of active sites [6,21]. Consequently, it is crucial to identify catalytic materials with high physicochemical stability and a substantial active surface area for implementing sulfur mediators in LSBs separators. ZrO2, a renowned catalyst and support material for oxygen reduction and lithium batteries, has recently garnered significant attention from the scientific community due to its intrinsic characteristics, including ultrahigh thermal stability, low cost, and the presence of both acid-base centers [22,23]. However, ZrO2 is a typical phase-dependent material, meaning that different crystalline forms of ZrO2 exhibit specific properties suited for different applications. In catalysis, ZrO2 with tetragonal phases demonstrates the highest activity and sensitivity contrast to the monoclinic or cubic phases, which can be attributed to the interesting feature of tetragonal phase with intrinsic defects of oxygen vacancies [24,25]. During the formation of tetragonal phases, with the escape of oxygen, two extra electrons are introduced into the lattice. Due to the difficulty of reducing ZrO2, the outer electronic are trapped in the vacancy site rather than reducing the nearest Zr ion, determining the ZrO2 has good electrical conductivity to boost the electrocatalytic reaction [24,26]. Furthermore, the superficial unsaturated coordination of Zr atoms in tetragonal phases suggests that ZrO2 possesses a higher affinity and activity for adsorbing and accelerating reactant conversion. As mentioned earlier, tetragonal phases of ZrO2 with high conductivity and catalytic activity hold great potential as sulfur mediators in LSBs, as they can inhibit sulfur dissolution and enhance conversion kinetics. Unfortunately, directly using tetragonal phases of ZrO2 with intrinsic surface defects as sulfur mediators in LSBs does not yield the expected performance due to insufficient active sites [27,28]. Introducing defect engineering is a common method for regulating surface properties of nanomaterials through reduction [29–31]. However, forming oxygen vacancies on the surface of ZrO2 is challenging due to its low reducibility, even in strong reducing atmospheres at high temperatures (∼900 °C) and pressures of 120 kPa [32]. Therefore, it is highly valuable to develop an efficient strategy for engineering stable surface oxygen vacancies on tetragonal phases of ZrO2 particles at lower temperatures and pressures. This approach will provide more active sites and reaction interfaces, increasing the collision probability between polysulfides and sulfur mediators and promoting their conversion. Based on the comprehensive analysis above, we have successfully developed tetragonal phases of ZrO2 −x with abundant oxygen vacancies on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH) using a hydrogen-etching method at relatively low temperature and pressure. In this design, the CNTs-OH skeleton serves as a highly conductive network that provides steric effects to inhibit the growth of ZrO2 −x particle size. The small particle size of the initial ZrO2 and the presence of sufficient –OH groups on CNTs-OH facilitate the easy reduction of ZrO2 surface even at low temperature and pressure. The resulting abundant oxygen vacancies effectively modify the crystalline structure and electron cloud density of ZrO2 −x , thereby enhancing its conductivity and sulfur affinity. As a result, this thoughtfully engineered ZrO2 −x with enriched vacancies, coupled with a desirable carbon matrix, exhibits a synergistic relationship among electron transport, chemical adsorption, and catalytic conversion for polysulfides. Experimental results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations also demonstrate that ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH possesses high conductivity and excellent sulfur affinity, acting as a mediator for polysulfide confinement and conversion, leading to a controlled shuttle effect and improved cycling stability. Benefiting from these merits, the LSBs coupled with a ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH-coated separator exhibit superior specific capacity, prolonged cycling life, and excellent rate performance. Notably, even at a high sulfur loading of 5 mg cm − 2, the battery equipped with a ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH-coated separator demonstrates outstanding performance, with an initial areal capacity of 5.6 mA h cm − 2 and a retained areal capacity of 4.2 mA h cm − 2 after 50 cycles. 2 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the synthesis process of oxygen-rich vacancy tetragonal phases ZrO2 −x /CNT-OH. As reported previously, the UiO-66-OH is prepared using zirconium chloride and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid as precursors through the solvothermal method [33]. During this process, CNTs-OH are also added to disperse and support the UIO-66-OH. The incorporation of CNTs-OH network provides a steric effect, resulting in the formation of small particle-sized UiO-66 with abundant –OH groups. Subsequently, the obtained UiO-66-OH is subjected to calcination in a hydrogen atmosphere at 550 °C for 5 h. This leads to the formation of nanoscale ZrO2 particles derived from UiO-66-OH, which facilitates lower formation energies of ZrO2 and increased reducibility. Moreover, in the presence of –OH, the hydrogen etching process causes oxygen to detach from the lattice, resulting in the introduction of two extra electrons. These electrons are trapped in the vacancy site rather than reducing the nearest Zr ion, thereby participating in the reduction of ZrO2 and promoting surface reduction. Consequently, the synthesis yields small, pure tetragonal phases of ZrO2 −x /CNT-OH with oxygen defects, effectively narrowing the band gap of ZrO2 and enhancing electron conductivity. The morphology and microstructure of ZrO2 are analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) as shown in Fig. 1(b–d) and Fig. S1. A comparison between octahedral ZrO2 particles obtained from UIO-66 carbonization (with a size of approximately 350 nm) and the nanoscale spherical ZrO2 −x derived from UIO-66-OH (with an average size of 25 ± 15 nm) reveals that the latter is anchored on the surface of CNTs-OH. Through investigating the dispersion of ZrO2 −x within ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH as shown in supporting information (Fig. S2), the ratio of ZrO2 −x derived from UIO-66-OH to CNTs-OH is selected (UIO-66-OH: CNTs-OH = 10:1). Furthermore, the TEM image in Fig. 1(e) confirms that the addition of CNTs-OH effectively hinders the growth of ZrO2 −x nanoparticles. To investigate the crystal structure of the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) is employed as shown in Fig. 1(f). The surface of the ZrO2 −x nanoparticles exhibits clear lattice stripes, with a stripe spacing of 0.296 nm, matching the stripe spacing of the (1 0 1) crystalline plane of ZrO2 [34]. The distortion of lattice stripes observed in the inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) image (Fig. 1g) provides distinct evidence of abundant oxygen vacancies in ZrO2 −x nanoparticles. This indicates that small particle size and sufficient –OH groups are conducive to promoting the reduction of ZrO2 during the hydrogen etching process. Furthermore, the high-magnification element distribution mapping images in Fig. 1h demonstrate that Zr, O, and C are uniformly distributed, confirming that ZrO2 −x particles are tightly anchored on the surface of CNTs-OH. The crystallographic structures of the as-designed ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH are determined using X-ray diffraction (XRD), and the reflection patterns are compared with those of ZrO2/CNTs-OH and CNTs-OH. In Fig. 2 (a), the characteristic peaks at 30.236°, 50.255°, and 60.204° correspond to the (1 0 1), (1 1 2), and (2 1 1) crystallographic planes of ZrO2, respectively. After undergoing the H2 etching procedure, the half peak widths of these three characteristic peaks in ZrO2 −x /CNT-OH are significantly broader, indicating the successful introduction of oxygen defects. Additionally, a characteristic peak at 26.002° corresponding to the (0 0 2) diffraction peak of CNTs is also observed in ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, which is beneficial for reducing the ZrO2 particle size and improving its reducibility. The size-regulated and morphology-adjusted ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH material exhibits a specific surface area of 242.46 m2 g − 1 and pore volumes of 0.814 cm3 g − 1, as shown in Fig. 2(b) and Fig. S3, surpassing those of ZrO2/CNTs-OH. This increase in surface area and pore volume, combined with the results from SEM and TEM images, can be attributed to the introduction of defect sites and the small particle size, further confirming the effect of CNTs-OH. It is noteworthy that the porous pore structures and the presence of sufficient oxygen defects can concurrently facilitate ion conductivity enhancement and electrocatalytic activity improvement for the sulfur cathode. This is also confirmed by the electrolyte wettability tests shown in Fig. 2(c). On the blank and ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator, the contact angles are 43.9° and 9.4°, respectively. In contrast, the electrolyte rapidly permeated the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator, indicating the excellent hydrophilicity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, which facilitates the transfer of ions for sulfur conversion. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is employed to further investigate the electronic valence changes of oxygen and Zr before and after H2 etching. As shown in Fig. 2(d), three peaks corresponding to oxygen are observed at 530.77, 532.05, and 533.09 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen, vacancy oxygen, and adsorbed oxygen, respectively. In comparison, the ratio of vacancy oxygen to lattice oxygen in ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH is 0.79, which is much higher than that of ZrO2/CNTs-OH (0.24), confirming the successful introduction of oxygen vacancies. Simultaneously, the Zr 3d spectrum (Fig. 2e) is deconvoluted into four bands at 185.20, 184.71 eV (3d 3/2), and 182.85, 182.36 eV (3d 5/2), indicating the presence of Zr3+ [35]. The proportion of Zr3+ in ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH is much higher than that in ZrO2/CNTs-OH, suggesting a higher electron-cloud density in ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH due to the presence of oxygen vacancies on the surface. The defective features of oxygen are further investigated using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis (Fig. 2f), which reveals a distinct resonance signal at a g-factor of 2.003 in ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, compared to ZrO2/CNTs-OH, confirming the existence of abundant oxygen vacancies [36,37]. Collectively, these results demonstrate the successful elimination of a fraction of oxygen atoms in the synthesized ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH material and the evident variation in the local electronic distribution. This optimized electronic environment is expected to enhance sulfur utilization and boost the redox reaction kinetics. To further investigate the effect of oxygen vacancies on the surface of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, the electronic distributions near the Fermi energy level are examined. As shown in Fig. 2(g−j), pristine ZrO2 exhibits regular electronic distributions with a distinct band gap around the Fermi energy level. However, upon introducing oxygen vacancies on the surface of ZrO2 −x , the charge distribution becomes disordered (Fig. 2h), and the states cross the Fermi level, as depicted in the density of states (DOS) plots. This indicates that the introduced oxygen vacancies truly reconstruct the surface charge density, activating the catalytic activity of ZrO2 −x and enhancing the electronic conductivity capability between ZrO2 −x and polysulfides. The improved charge transfer capability is further supported by conductivity tests. As shown in Fig. S4, the electrical conductivity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH is an order of magnitude higher than that of ZrO2/CNTs-OH, thereby enhancing the overall electrochemical performance of LSBs. Apart from electron conduction and charge transfer, molecule adsorption and the regulation of adsorption energy and conversion rates are also crucial factors for electrochemical redox reactions. To compare the adsorption abilities of sulfur mediators towards polysulfide intermediates, visual experiments on the adsorption of Li2S6 are conducted, as depicted in Fig. 3 (a). The change in color represents the concentration variation of polysulfides in the solution. After 12 h, the Li2S6 solution containing ZrO2/CNTs-OH exhibits a lighter color compared to the pure Li2S6 solution, while the Li2S6 solution with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH becomes colorless, indicating the rapid and enhanced adsorption affinity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH. This observation is further confirmed by ex situ ultraviolet (UV) spectra. The characteristic peak corresponding to S6 2 − at around 280 nm displays the lowest intensity in the Li2S6 solution with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, providing strong evidence for the strong trapping ability of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH towards Li2S6 and its effective suppression of the shuttle effect of polysulfides [19,38]. Additionally, the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator also demonstrates an excellent shielding effect for polysulfides, as demonstrated in the H-shaped glass cell experiment. In this experiment, the left side of the H-shaped glass cell contains an electrolyte with Li2S6, the right side contains an equal amount of pure electrolyte, and the modified separator is positioned in the middle. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the electrolyte on the right side turns deep yellow after 10 h, indicating the easy diffusion of Li2S6 across the blank separator. However, when using the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator, the electrolyte on the right side becomes bright yellow due to a certain extent of anchoring effect for polysulfides. In contrast, the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits excellent capability to block polysulfides, as the electrolyte on the right side remains colorless after 10 h, further confirming the strong affinity between ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH and polysulfides. The adsorption of Li2S6 on ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH is investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to probe its interaction. In the S2p spectra (Fig. S5a and b), a new peak corresponding to the Zr–S bond can be observed, confirming the strong chemical interaction between the transition metal and sulfur. Furthermore, in Fig. 3(c), the Zr3d signal can be deconvoluted into four peaks at 185.20, 184.71 eV (3d 3/2), and 182.85, 182.36 eV (3d 5/2), corresponding to Zr3+ and Zr4+. After adsorbing Li2S6, both the Zr3d 3/2 and Zr3d 5/2 peaks slightly shift towards a lower binding energy, indicating that electrons may transfer from Li2S6 to Zr sites [35]. This result also implies the strong interaction between ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH with rich oxygen vacancies and polysulfides, which is further confirmed by DFT calculations at the molecular level. The optimized adsorption geometries of Li2S6 on ZrO2 −x and ZrO2 are illustrated in Fig. 3(d–f). It is evident that Zr atoms preferentially bond with S, which aligns with the XPS analysis results. Particularly, the adsorption energy between Li2S6 and ZrO2 −x is −4.89 eV higher compared to ZrO2 (−1.72 eV), and the Zr–S bond length between Li2S6 and ZrO2 −x is 2.39 Å as well shorter than that in ZrO2. The higher adsorption energy and shorter bond length in ZrO2 −x are advantageous for the adsorption and anchoring of polysulfides, thereby accelerating their conversion. The charge density differences between the optimized geometries of Li2S6 on ZrO2 and ZrO2 −x are displayed in Fig. 3(g and h). Blue and green colors indicate charge accumulation and depletion, respectively. The denser charge accumulation in the Li2S6-ZrO2 −x system further supports the aforementioned conclusion. Clearly, the electron cloud density of Li2S6 in ZrO2 −x is significantly higher than that in ZrO2, indicating that oxygen defects in ZrO2 −x effectively enhance the charge transfer between Li2S6 and ZrO2 −x , thereby improving the trapping ability of polysulfides and promoting the kinetics of sulfur conversion. Rapid diffusion of lithium ions plays a crucial role in accelerating the kinetics of the lithium polysulfide reaction and suppressing the shuttle effect. To investigate the Li+ diffusion kinetics, cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests are conducted on LSBs with different modified separators. Fig. S6(a–c) presents the first three cycles of LSBs using ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, ZrO2/CNTs-OH, and blank separators at a sweep rate of 0.1 mV s − 1. It is evident that similar electrochemical behaviors, characterized by two pairs of redox peaks, are observed in all three batteries. The first reduction peak, located at 2.3 V, corresponds to the reduction of S8 to long-chain lithium polysulfide (Li2S x , x = 8, 6, 4). The second reduction peak, positioned at 2.05 V, corresponds to the conversion of long-chain lithium polysulfides to short-chain Li2S2 and Li2S. However, the onset reduction potential of LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator is significantly higher than that of the other batteries, indicating that ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH effectively promotes the conversion of long-chain lithium polysulfides to short-chain lithium polysulfides. Moreover, the CV curves of LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibit a high degree of overlap, providing strong evidence that ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH enhances the redox reversibility of polysulfides. To further investigate the diffusion characteristics of Li+ with different modified separators, CV tests are conducted at various scan rates (0.1–0.5 mV s − 1) (Fig. 4 a–c). Even with increasing current density, the CV curves of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH retained their original shape and exhibit the highest peak current compared to ZrO2/CNTs-OH and the blank separator. This further demonstrates that ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH enhances the reversibility and ion transfer rate of the polysulfide redox reaction. Additionally, the efficiency of Li+ diffusion is determined using the Randles-Sevcik equation [39,40]. (1) I p = 2.69 × 10 5 n 1.5 A D Li + 0.5 C Li + v 0.5 where I p is the peak current, n is the number of electrons, A is the area of the electrode, D Li + is the Li+ diffusion rate, C Li + is the concentration of Li+ in the electrolyte, and v is the scanning speed. With the given parameters of n, A, and C, the relationship between the peak current and the square root of the sweep velocity is linear, and the slope of the fitting curve reflects the diffusion rate of Li+. As shown in Fig. 4(d–f) and Fig. S7(a and b), the fitted lines of peaks A, B, C, and D for ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH are steeper than those for ZrO2/CNTs-OH and the blank separator. This indicates that the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator possesses the highest Li+ transfer rate (4.69 × 10 − 8, 6.16 × 10 − 8, 4.27 × 10 − 8 and 1.04 × 10 − 8 cm2 s − 1, respectively). This advantage can be attributed to the introduction of oxygen vacancies, which facilitates the acceleration of polysulfide conversion during the entire charge/discharge process. The ion conductivity profiles of the batteries with different separators, according to the ion conductivity formula, are shown in Fig. 4(g). Based on the electrochemical impedance results of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH and ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (Fig. 4h), the Li+ conductivity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator is calculated to be 1.036 mS cm − 1, higher than that of ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (0.901 mS cm − 1) and the initial PP separator (0.555 mS cm − 1) in Fig. S8 [41]. Similarly, the Li+ transference numbers test (Fig. 4i) supports these findings. Through testing initial and steady currents for the symmetrical battery with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator, ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and pure PP separator, the calculated Li+ transference number for the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator is 0.676, higher than that of the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (0.619) and PP (0.539). This strongly confirms the excellent Li+ conductivity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH. The advantage of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH can be attributed to its improved roughness, enhanced polarity, and increased surface energy after introducing oxygen vacancies, all of which contribute to accelerating the polysulfide redox kinetics. To demonstrate the electrocatalytic activity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH in polysulfide conversion, symmetric cells are assembled using Li2S6 as the active material. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the symmetric cells exhibit two pairs of reversible redox peaks in the range of −0.8 to 0.8 V at sweep rates of 10 and 50 mV s − 1, respectively (Fig. 5a, Fig. S9). Comparing the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH electrode to the ZrO2/CNTs-OH and blank electrodes, the symmetric cell with the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH electrode shows higher response current, distinct oxygen and reduction peaks, and lower overpotential between the redox peaks. This indicates that ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH possesses superior catalytic ability for polysulfide conversion. The low polarization potential is advantageous for enhancing the electrochemical conversion kinetics, which is further supported by the LSBs assembled with different material-modified separators at a sweep rate of 0.1 mV s − 1. As depicted in Fig. 5(b), the reduction peak for the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator shifts to a higher potential compared to the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and pure PP, while the oxidation peak shifts to a lower potential. LSBs assembled with the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits smaller polarization and sharper peaks, further confirming the excellent catalytic effect of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH on polysulfide redox kinetics. Furthermore, ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH demonstrates a higher response current, indicating a higher specific discharge capacity and significantly improving the utilization rate of active substances. The pronounced increase in redox peak current observed for the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator, in contrast to the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and pure PP, also confirms the enhanced electrochemical conversion of polysulfides. Thus, ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH with abundant oxygen vacancies emerges as the most efficient catalyst for boosting polysulfide conversion. These findings are further supported by electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with its corresponding equivalent circuits. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits the smallest charge transfer resistance (37.4 Ω) and ion diffusion resistance compared to the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (59.9 Ω) and PP (73 Ω). These improvements can be attributed to the enhanced catalytic activity and improved electrical conductivity introduced by oxygen vacancies in facilitating polysulfide conversion. To compare the catalytic effect of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH on polysulfides conversion, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) of LSBs with different materials and their corresponding parallel samples are conducted at 0.1C. In Fig. 5(d–f), two distinct plateaus can be observed during the discharge process. The upper plateau corresponds to the conversion of S8 to Li2S n (n = 4, 6, 8), while the lower plateau is attributed to the conversion process of soluble polysulfides to Li2S. Based on the GITT curves of the three LSBs with different separators and their parallel samples, the deposit time of Li2S on the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator accounts for 29.5% of the total time, compared to 29.8% for the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and 30.6% for the PP separator, suggesting its most efficient catalytic effect for polysulfides redox reaction. This result can also be confirmed by the overpotential comparison (the sudden voltage drop). Obviously, the overpotential for the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator is smaller than that for the other two LSBs. Furthermore, the internal reaction resistances of the three LSBs with different separators are calculated using the following equation [42]. (2) Δ R = Δ V Q O C V - C C V / I a p p l i e d where R represents the internal reaction resistance, ΔV denotes the difference between the quasi-open-circuit voltage (QOCV) and closed-circuit voltage (CCV), and I applied denotes the applied current. The LSBs with the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits the lowest internal reaction resistance, in contrast to the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and PP. This finding confirms that ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, with abundant oxygen defects, possesses excellent catalytic capability and exhibits the lowest electrochemical polarization during the sulfur reduction reaction process. These factors contribute to the enhanced conversion kinetics of polysulfides, as confirmed by the potentiostatic nucleation of Li2S. According to Faraday's law, the specific capacity of Li2S deposition on the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator (226.3 mA h g − 1) is significantly higher than that on the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (189.8 mA h g − 1) and PP (162.2 mA h g − 1). Additionally, the responsivity of Li2S nucleation is much faster, and the precipitation area of Li2S is larger for the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator (t = 611.2 s) compared to the ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (t = 733.4 s) and PP (t = 1368.8 s). Furthermore, the SEM images of the cathode with or without ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator are also obtained after Li2S deposition as shown in Fig. S10. Obviously, the surface of the cathode without ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator contains large agglomerations of insulating Li2S/Li2S2, whereas the cathode with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator has a loose hollow structure, although its surface is covered by a slight aggregation of Li2S/Li2S2. These results demonstrate that the introduction of oxygen defects can effectively reduce the overpotential for Li2S deposition, thus accelerating the sulfur reduction reaction kinetics. According to the previous reports, the reduction of Li2S2 to Li2S is the rate-limiting step for LSBs [43]. To further investigate the catalytic influence of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, First-principles Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations are performed. As shown in Fig. 5 (j−k), the energy barrier for the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S on the surface of ZrO2 −x is 0.48 eV, whereas the conversion on the surface of ZrO2 exhibits a higher energy barrier of 1.48 eV, demonstrating that the introduction of oxygen vacancies can effectively enhance the catalytic effect of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH for polysulfides conversion inhibiting the shuttle effect. To assess the impact of separators made of different materials on battery performance, galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) voltage curves are plotted in Fig. 6 (a). Two distinct charge–discharge plateaus corresponding to the polysulfide conversion process are observed, consistent with the CV results. The LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits a high initial discharge specific capacity of 1451.5 mA h g − 1, indicating that the introduction of oxygen effectively enhanced the conductivity and adsorption of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH. This improvement led to enhanced active sulfur utilization and reduced loss of polysulfides. Notably, the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits the lowest polarization potential (ΔE) compared to ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and pure PP, demonstrating the high reversibility of polysulfide redox facilitated by ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH. Specifically, the overpotential for Li2S oxidation and nucleation processes in LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator is approximately half of those in the original LSBs (Fig. S11), indicating the remarkable catalytic activity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH for polysulfide redox kinetics. Fig. 6(b) illustrates the rate performance of LSBs with various modified separators at current densities ranging from 0.1 to 5C (1 C = 1672 mA g − 1). The LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibit capacities of 1451, 1155, 1012, 935, 861, 768, and 651 mA h g − 1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5C, respectively, surpassing those of the other modified separators. This further confirms its remarkable catalytic activity. When the current density reverts back to 0.1 C, the discharge capacity recovers to 1240 mA h g − 1, indicating excellent reversibility and rate capabilities. Importantly, despite an increase in polarization with increasing current density, the GCD profile of LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator (Fig. 6c) still maintains two distinct charge–discharge plateaus even at a current density as high as 5 C. This strongly supports its higher activity for the Li-S redox reactions compared to LSBs with ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and PP (Fig. S12a and b). To investigate the catalytic effect of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH on LSBs performance, the capacities of the first and second discharge platforms are defined as Q 1 and Q 2, respectively, and compared as shown in Fig. 6(d and e). Based on the mechanism of the sulfur reduction process, the ratio of Q 2/Q 1 is used to indicate the electrocatalytic activity of the separator mediator in polysulfide conversion. The histogram of statistical Q 2/Q 1 values for various batteries is presented in Fig. 6(e). Impressively, the LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits the highest ratio of 2.8 at 0.1C, in contrast to ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and PP. This ratio is close to the theoretical value of 3.0, clearly demonstrating the outstanding catalytic activity of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH in promoting the redox reaction of polysulfides. In addition, the long-term cycling stabilities of LSBs with various separators are investigated at a current density of 0.5C and sulfur area loading of 1.5 mg cm − 2 (electrolyte/sulfur, E/S = 10.8 μL mg − 1). As shown in Fig. 6(f), the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits a high initial discharge specific capacity of 1054 mA h g − 1, significantly higher than that of LSBs with ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator (911.7 mA h g − 1) and PP (803.6 mA h g − 1). Even after 200 cycles, the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator maintains a discharge capacity of 815 mA h g − 1, with a capacity retention of 77.5% and a coulombic efficiency (CE) close to 100%. Similar results are obtained from the cycling stability measurement of LSBs at 1 C (Fig. S13). The LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits an outstanding initial capacity of 938.2 mA h g − 1 and superior cyclability, with a low-capacity degradation of only 0.06% after 400 cycles, confirming its high reversibility and rapid polysulfide conversion kinetics. This excellent reversibility is further supported by the consistent charge–discharge voltage platforms before and after 400 cycles (Fig. S14). Furthermore, even at an ultra-high current density of 3C (Fig. 6g), the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator demonstrates a long cycling life, with an extremely low-capacity decay of only 0.03% per cycle after 1000 cycles. This performance surpasses that of previous modified separators (Fig. 6h, Table S1) [41,44–54]. In contrast, the LSBs with ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and pure PP separator exhibit the lowest initial capacities of 684.1 and 548.9 mA h g − 1, respectively, and rapidly degraded to 310 mA h g − 1 after 990 and 660 cycles, indicating their significantly reduced cyclability. The stable cycling performance of LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator can be attributed to the effective anchor effect on polysulfide diffusion and superior catalytic activity for polysulfide conversion achieved through the introduction of oxygen vacancies. Based on the characterization and analysis conducted above, it is evident that the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator offers significant advantages in improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs. The presence of abundant oxygen defects on the ZrO2 −x surface plays a crucial role in effectively inhibiting polysulfide shuttle phenomena, facilitating their rapid conversion, promoting electrolyte penetration, and enhancing the transfer rate of Li+. Simultaneously, the CNTs-OH skeleton acts as a highly conductive network, providing an excellent platform for accelerated charge transfer and effectively intercepting and confining polysulfides within the cathode (Fig. 7 a). To assess the applicability of the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator, LSBs with high sulfur loadings are investigated. Even at a high sulfur loading of 3.5 mg cm − 2, the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator demonstrated two distinct discharge plateaus, as observed in Fig. 7(b). Moreover, the initial discharge capacity of 1288 mA h g − 1 significantly surpasses that of the pure PP separator, indicating the efficient catalytic conversion of soluble polysulfides to insoluble Li2S facilitates by ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH. Notably, the overpotential for the LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator is only 26 mV, considerably lower than that of the original LSBs (34 mV) as shown in Fig. 7(c). This further confirms the enhanced kinetics of polysulfide conversion by ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH, owing to its robust chemisorption and catalytic activation properties. To further evaluate the capability of the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator, both the initial area capacity and long-term cycling stability are tested. Fig. 7(d) illustrates the desirable first discharge specific capacities achieved by LSBs with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator at different sulfur loadings. At a high sulfur loading of 6.0 mg cm − 2 (E/S = 5.1 µL mg − 1), a remarkable discharge specific capacity of 1050 mA h g − 1 is obtained, corresponding to high areal capacities of 6.3 mA h cm − 2 (Fig. 7e). After 20 cycles, the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator still delivers a high reversible area capacity of 5.1 mA h cm − 2 (Fig. S15). Moreover, the superior cycling performance exhibited by the LSB with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator under a higher sulfur loading of 5 mg cm − 2 and a lean electrolyte condition (E/S = 8 µL mg − 1) is also obtained in Fig. 7f. Even after 50 cycles, a high reversible area capacity of 4.2 mA h cm − 2 is retained (much higher than that of LSB with pure PP separator, 1.5 mA h cm − 2), demonstrating a capacity retention of 75% (Fig. S16). This finding is consistent with the comparison of voltage platforms before and after 50 cycles, where almost no change is observed (Fig. 7g). These results strongly validate the improved electrical conductivity, enhanced Li+ transfer rate, reduced dissolution diffusion, and enhanced redox kinetics achieved through the meticulously designed structure and the introduction of abundant defect engineering. Furthermore, the advantageous performance of the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator in polysulfide conversion is exemplified by the surface morphology comparison of the Li anode before and after 50 cycles. As anticipated, the surface of the cycled Li in LSBs assembled with ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator remains relatively smooth and shows no significant deviation from its pristine morphology (Fig. 7i). In contrast, the surfaces of the cycled Li in LSBs assembled with ZrO2/CNTs-OH modified separator and pure PP exhibit noticeable lithium bumps and cracks (Fig. 7j−k). Consequently, the polar ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits a strong adsorption and anchoring effect on polysulfides, effectively inhibiting polysulfide shuttle phenomena, mitigating lithium dendrite formation, and improving the cycling stability of LSBs. Based on the experimental results and DFT calculations presented above, the developed ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator holds significant promise for practical applications in powering electronic devices. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully achieved the introduction of sufficient oxygen vacancies into small crystal size tetragonal phases of ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH through a hydrogen-etching method, enabling the tuning of its electrochemical activity for LSBs under low temperature and pressure conditions. The elaborately constructed ZrO2 −x coupled with a desirable carbon matrix exhibits a synergistic relationship among electron transport, chemical adsorption, and catalytic conversion of polysulfides. By combining experimental and theoretical analysis, we have analyzed and discussed in detail the adsorption-diffusion-catalytic mechanism of oxygen defects on polysulfide conversion. The oxygen vacancies created in ZrO2 −x not only significantly optimize the surface electronic distribution to accelerate charge transfer but also remarkably enhance its sulfiphilicity, inhibiting polysulfide migration. Additionally, the increased active sites on the ZrO2 −x surface, achieved through morphology tuning and electronic structure optimization, effectively reduce the reaction barrier and increase Li+ transfer rate, thereby accelerating the polysulfide redox kinetics during Li2S nucleation process. As a result, the ZrO2 −x /CNTs-OH modified separator exhibits ultra-high rate performance (938.2 mA h g − 1 at 1.0 C), excellent cycling stability (capacity decay rate of 0.03% per cycle after 1000 cycles at 3.0 C), and competitive areal capacity (6.3 mA h cm − 2 under a high sulfur loading of 6 mg cm − 2). This work provides a novel strategy for designing defects engineering on hardly-reducible oxides for advanced LSBs, which can be extended to other electrocatalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: The recent emergence of tetragonal phases zirconium dioxide (ZrO2) with vacancies has generated significant interest as a highly efficient and stable electrocatalyst with potential applications in trapping polysulfides and facilitating rapid conversion in lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). However, the reduction of ZrO2 is challenging, even under strong reducing atmospheres at high temperatures and pressures. Consequently, the limited presence of oxygen vacancies results in insufficient active sites and reaction interfaces, thereby hindering practical implementation. Herein, we successfully introduced abundant oxygen vacancies into ZrO2 at the nanoscale with the help of carbon nanotubes (CNTs-OH) through hydrogen-etching at lower temperatures and pressures. The introduced oxygen vacancies on ZrO2− x /CNTs-OH can effectively rearrange charge distribution, enhance sulfiphilicity and increase active sites, contributing to high ionic and electronic transfer kinetics, strong binding energy and low redox barriers between polysulfides and ZrO2− x . These findings have been experimentally validated and supported by theory calculations. As a result, LSBs assembled with the ZrO2− x /CNTs-OH modified separators demonstrate excellent rate performance, superior cycling stability, and ultra-high sulfur utilization. Especially, at high sulfur loading of 6 mg cm−2, the area capacity is still up to 6.3 mA h cm−2. This work provides valuable insights into the structural and functional optimization of electrocatalysts for batteries.
